description.text:
I wanted to jack up my new MendelMax so I can mount my power supply under there, but didn't like the look of any of the legs I could find on Thingiverse so I made these.  They match the profile of the existing base pieces to keep things sexy and bolt through the bottom holes. 
They are 1.8" (approx 45.75mm) tall, which was more than enough to fit my power supply and primarily sized to fit the 50mm bolts I already had. 
I'm a mesh modeler, so I don't have SCAD to share, sorry.

Print two times, front and back pairs.  
I printed with 20% infill and they are plenty sturdy.  I slathered some ABS/acetone goo between these and the base pieces to make sure they stay straight since there's only one bolt per riser.  
Hold in place with the a slot-nut in the bottom of the extrusion and an M5 50mm bolt.

author: jmartic

description.text:
This is a printable fretboard for a 4/4 violin. It is also a work in progress so your feedback and remixes are requested.
I just taped it onto the fingerboard with painters tape, which works alright but doesnt look as good as adhesive backing or clips.
After printing, remove the foot.
To install, loosen the strings a note or two and slide it under and then up the neck until flush with the nut. Apply tape and retune.
I think I made about 5 versions before uploading but some areas which need work are fret spacing as it seems to be less than a quarter note off between strings. Also the curvature of the neck took a few times to get right, but may differ a bit from instrument to instrument. if this is off, it will cause the board to lift up on the edges or center and touch strings.

Work in progress. I will try to revisit the project in a few months and incorporate suggestions.

-Corey

Thanks to David, creator of fffiddle for getting me into strings.

description.text: This is the Braille Thing? It's an educational system designed to help Low Vision and Blind students learn and produce simple Braille letter through an interactive system. There is a clip on board that has cut out's for changeable magnets that can make up any six character or less words. Under the larger cut out are a replica of the six cells used in Braille. There are printed dots that have magnets as well to produce the above letter in Braille. For a new Braille learner this process can be difficult and at some times straight up boring. I designed this for a student who is rapidly losing her vision and will eventually be a Braille media learner, out of all the Braille learning activities this was the one she would ask for on a daily basis. It's used in conjunction with an All In One board from APH. Here is a link to a video explaining this system.

title: 2020 Slider
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Work in Progress

I will build a 3d FDM printer myself in the next months and want to try something else for the X axis carriage, also I wanted to use the E3D V6 holder for the Anet A8 by TNS (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577) to fit onto the slide, therefor I took the measurments of the screw hole distances from the original A8 slide.
I designed all screw-holes and the nut inserts to fit the standard M3 bolts and nuts.
The mounts for the bearings and the bearing sleve are made to fit the 608 bearings.

After this thing is completed, I'll setup a test rig with a Stepper driver and a RAMPS board and will do a test where the slide will be running 24/7 until a set travel distance is reached (I'm thinking of a distance like 100km of travel or so) and afterwards I'll look at the wear an the rollers and the extrusion (perhaps I'll do one test with a aluminium extrusion and one with a printed one for comparison)

Things todo:

  • Add a 2020 Mounting bracket so that you can use the slide as a carriage for a 2020 Extrusion
  • Add a Nema 17 holder to fit a stepper if you wont use CoreXY

Good Thing noticed: It'll fit an 2040 Extrusion as well.

Pre-Build requirements (I designed this thing to use M3 hex cap screws):

Hardware:

  • 2*M3x20 Screws (6 if using beltholder for mounting the belt holder in the links below) (2 upper bearing mounts)
  • 1*M3x12 Screw (lower bearing mount)
  • 10*M3x10 screws (for mounting the extruder carriage, varies from what you need)
  • 3*608zz or 608rs bearings (bought them cheap from china in packs of 10, lookup a local reseller, they might sell them cheaper)

Printed Parts:

  • 1*Slider_Base.Stl
  • 1*Slider.Stl (print more if you modify your existing printer, just in case you break some)
  • 3*Bearingholder.Stl Rotate by 180°(print more if you modify your existing printer, just in case you break some)
  • OR 1 Bearingholder.Stl and 1 Bearing_holder_for_belt.Stl
  • 3*608Sleve.Stl (print more, you will need them in the future as they wear down, print them in nylon if you can)

Tools:

  • Pair of pliers (it might be possible to hold down the bearing holders while screwing the screw into them)
  • M3 hex wrench
  • lightweight hammer for inserting the bearing holders into the bearings (designed the OD of the holders to be just 8mm, so the fit will be defined by the tolerance of your printer, when they don't fit, print them with a lower or higher scale like 99-101% in the X and Y direction)

Links:
E3D V6 Mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577
Belt attachement https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1433295

Updates:
02.10.17:

  • Added stronger slider base for less flex on the mount of the single bearing

28.06.17:

  • added one more hole to the belt attachement so that you can mount the belt attachement upside down

27.06.17:

  • Added belt attachement bearing holder
  • Added links to hings I use above
  • Removed WIP status

26.06.17:

  • Removed the nut insert for the adjsutment slide because I had a hard time to fit it so that a M3x12 screw would reach the nut, the screw will now screw into the plastik so be carefull!
  • More size adjustments like increasing the distance between the 2 longholes by 2 mm
  • Many little adjustments and prototyping
  • Added quick note/copmparison between moving weight in a CoreXY printer (see below)

23.06.17:

  • Enlarged spacing between longholes
  • Enlarged the thicknes of the base plate to fit standard m3 bolt sizes
  • Enlarged depthness of the nut holders
  • Enlarge all screwholes so the screws will only screw into the nut, not the plastik (sometimes they still screw into the plastik but not too tightly anymore, could depend on printer)
  • Turned around the hole pattern so it isn't upside down

21.06.17:

  • Highered the thicknes of the plate for nut inserts on both sides and less flex,
  • enlarged the longholes and modified them to fit an m3 nut,
  • redesigned the bearing holders. added 2 nut inserts and screwholes so that you can use the lower ones when using 2040 or use the upper ones when using 2020 extrusion

Feel free to comment and share your ideas about this thing and help me to develop it further.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

Quick note on moving wheights

I did a quick research about the moving mass of the parts I'm designing vs. standart linear guides.
(Here I thought about a CoreXY design with a Z Axis length of 0.5Meters)
Linear Rods:

  • 2*0.5M > 0.42 Kg
  • 2*SCE8LU 0.2 KG (LM8LUU with housing)
  • 4*SCE8UU 0.32 Kg (LM8UU with housing)
  • 2 Carriages ~ 0.02 Kg
  • 1 E3D V6 with carriage ~ 0.08 Kg

~= 1.04 Kg moving mass

2040 Extrusion:

  • 0.89Kg/m > 0.45 Kg
  • Slide, carriage and V6 ~0.16 Kg
  • 2 Slides ~0,1 Kg

~= 0.71 Kg moving mass

2020 Extrusion:

  • 0.49Kg/m > 0.25 Kg
  • Slide, carriage + V6 ~0.16 Kg
  • 2 Slides 0,1 Kg

~= 0,51 Kg moving mass

Conclusions:

  • If the Extrusion is stable and wear resistant enough, it would make a good replacement for linear rods
  • For a length of X, you have to choose 2040 becaus its stiffer on length
  • Steel Rods and bearings are heavy !
  • The less moving weight the better??
  • Have to try it....!

comments.text: So how far have you gotten? Have you tested this on actual 2020? I'm thinking about printing this out and seeing how it works. Would be cool to make an X and Y carriage design that drops in place of the SCS8UU bearing block. That way you could swap 8mm rods for 2020 extrusion and mount them straight to the already available  carriage plates.

title: Drill Bit Stand (Metric) with Additional Screwdriver Bit Slots

description.text:
I definitely needed a new drill bit stand for the random bits I have. So I quickly knocked up a stand which can hold 2mm-20mm drill bits (1mm increments) and can also hold screwdriver bits in the holes in the bottom of the stand. The holes are all designed to be .25mm bigger than the drill bit size, so make sure your printer is calibrated well as mine came out at about .15mm-.2mm bigger than the round drill bit number (ie. my 10.25mm hole printed at 10.15mm, so the bit fit really well). If your printer is calibrated wrong and it prints the holes smaller, than you will be in trouble as the bits wont fit! So double check your calibration, and DON'T BLAME ME IF YOU PRINT IT WRONG!

Overall dimensions are L145mm X W65mm X H54mm.

My print was 25% infill, 3 top and bottom layers with 3 perimeter lines. I use a raft on all my prints but you might not need one here but that's dependant on your own settings. Printed in red ABS. Print time was 12.5 hours.

They work with the original Crossfire and the Crossfire 2 frames and mount to the Bottom Plate via rubber dampener bushing (Hobby King). The four different trays are the basic ways to mount a camera. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:234867
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32281 Donate If you like my designs a small donation is greatly appreciated!
Donate

Print at 20% infill with supports on and raft off. Files:
BatteryTrayGP - Battery tray with a standard GoPro mount for a GoPro Case. BatteryTrayGimbal - Battery tray with a mount for a brushless gimbal. See thing here for more info and files: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140126 BatteryTrayServo - Battery tray for mounting a 9 gram servo to control camera pitch. BatteryTrayPlain - Battery tray with nothing on it, to mount using your own options or to modify. C1DampenerBottom - Bottom dampening plate for the original Crossfire. C2BottomPlate - Bottom dampening plate for Crossfire 2. TriBottomPlateDamp - Bottom dampening plate for the tricopter.

title: FT Gremlin LX400 Battery Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I decided to make a little flatter of a landing base as well as a battery holder/protector for my FT Gremlin.

I was not pleased with attaching the battery to the bottom as it would not fit between the screws and they dug into the battery. It was also very much open to being hurt on a hard landing as it was completely unprotected. As everyone knows damaged lipo are not happy lipo. This was my main driving factor.

It was also not very stable just sitting there. This made it hard to take off or land without tipping or hitting the blades on the ground.

Lastly, I needed to find different rubber bands that fit, since the black o-ring provided won't fit the batteries I bought.

So I thought, what the heck lets 3D print some stuff!

--

This module screws right to the frame bottom and has countersunk screw holes as well as antenna pass-through holes.

I put the battery lead out the front so it wraps neatly around the side to stay out of the way and help the battery not be able to side out since the wires would prevent that much movement.

Until I installed a buzzer, I was rubberbanding one of the low voltage battery alarms to the bottom making it easy to both hook up to the balance connector, as well as get a visual on the readout just by flying overhead my spotter.

This was only designed to fit the Lumenier 400 mAh 2S battery that FT sells.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

The higher the better

Depending on factors like shrinking and bridging you will probably have to sand down the insides to match your battery dimensions. I sanded mine down with a rasp until the batteries fit on the loose side, but just tight enough for them not to fall out.

description.text:
These are feet I made for my MP Select Mini.
The original stick on pads had come loose and shifted, so the base had a wobble to it.
Then after adding the 4DM maximus bed, There was a major wobble when the bed was homed, as there was too much weight hanging off the backside.

So I created some longer feet for the rear to account for this wobble. Standard beds should do fine with the small feet at both the front and rear. I also have added a "pad" for the small feet to be printed in TPU or other Flexible filaments. This pad is untested.

I used M3x10 Philips screws, but socket head screws should fit as well. Stock screws will not be long enough to get a good grip.

description.text:
This soap dish makes a good addition to any bathroom or kitchen sink because it lets the soap drain and prevents the soap from leaving residue on your sink, and if you print it out of plastic then cleaning it is easy because you can basically just rinse it off and let it air dry.

Just a side not you can click on the photos to expand them to make them better quality.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

In the Gcode I have the flow set to 150% because I have yet to re calibrate my extruder stepper motor so I would suggest changing that to what you normally use.

I find a bed temp of 60-80 degrees and a hot end temp of 235 degrees Centigrade works best but every plastic is different so adjust the temperatures to your liking in any slicer program or on your printer.

If your printer is good at bridging then you can disable the supports or modify them because it would reduce post processing time.

If you have anymore questions please feel free to contact me.

Removing the support material

In order to remove the support material I used a knife and I set it to not contact the part but sometimes it will fall over a little and a sharp knife or chisel works best for detaching it from the part.

This adapter lets people with hand limited movement push the nurse call button (a button with the shape of the picture above). The shape of this adapter don't flip on bed.

This object was made for the "Mutual de Seguridad C.Ch.C" from Chile. In a project of the Direction of innovation and development, and the Neuro rehabilitation institute.
1. pass the button by the bigger hole from bottom to top. 2. turn the button to fit in the smaller hole. The button will get stuck. 3. Put the button cover and turn it 90°.

description.text:
This bent tube acts like a tight, short barrel for modern 1/2"ish nerf darts and can be used with a T fitting and other tubes to make a gravity feed system out of an RSCB. As-printed, it fits nicely in 1/2" CPVC pipe fittings. Best suited for bullpup blasters, HAMPs, and any context where you can attach a barrel extension to this tube and stabilize that. Part of the intent here is to use minimal plastic and printing time and expect users to reinforce with non-3d printed (or larger, tougher 3d printed) parts.

Hoppers made from this so far seem to work well with suction cup elites and men gun darts, regardless of whether they are cut down.

The version presented was designed to be printed with an 0.6mm nozzle. Some adjustment may be needed to print well with other nozzles,

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.6mm nozzle

Infill:

none

Notes:

This Model may not work well for smaller or larger nozzles, this was designed to be exactly an inner and outer perimeter. Depending on what CAD software you're using, you may be able to adjust to get a similar print for your nozzle, just make the thickness an exact number (ideally 1 or 2) of perimeters.

A pronounced seam is inevitable and troubling, but the part seems to operate fine anyways.

comments.text: In my situation it doesn't seems like it is a hardware problem, looks more like a software issue.  When reviewing the layer by layer rendering of the print I can see that portions of the tabs are not being fully executed by SliC3r.  For example, it will print 50% of a tab, the outermost 50% on the first layer, so subsequent layers don't have a base to lay on.  I am learning as well, I just downloaded the newest version of Slic3r which seems to do a slightly better job at interpreting the stl file.  Slic3r can generate raft/skirt when I tell it to, and I have been using this feature when generating gcode, its not generating totally useless prints, but mine could use some refining.  Guess i'll have to adjust the code manually in order to compensate for software irregularities.  But I wont give up!  Still an awesome model!!  I have given one to most everyone I see on a daily basis and they cannot put it down.  I have found that ABS is better suited for this type of print, I acetone vapor treated the one I keep on my desk at work.
comments.author: 8bitlogic

comments.text: 8bitlogic, does your slicer program create a raft automatically? There is no raft included in the .stl file, and it needs to be added afterwards. The Makerbot software does this pretty well. If you are indeed using a raft and are still having problems, the supports may need to be modified for your equipment. I was able to print this several times successfully on a Makerbot2, but I am learning that subtle differences in equipment can lead to significant differences in printing of certain designs.

description.text:
A French Cleat is a method of holding tools by pairing two 45 degree angles together, in my case with 3/4 boards. A lot of people use Pegboards for the same purpose but many of us prefer the French Cleat design instead.

With so many great tool holder designs available for Pegboard on Thingiverse I decided to make it easier to use some of these designs on my French Cleats by pairing them together.

Since some tools can weigh quite a bit, I included moveable pegs that go on the back side of this to provide support.

For the pegboard I used: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2145069
You can connect additional pegboards with this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2145096

title: NYLON Windmill Flange to reduce Bird Mortality

description.text:
This is the mounting flange for a 2.5 meter 8 blade electrical generation windmill.
The flange is printed in NYLON so as to provide a shore 45 single piece flexible connection to the main drive shaft from eight fiberglass blades. The parts were printed on a 2BEIGH3 3D Printer. Details of the printer can be seen at:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Combination-CNC-Machine-and-3D-Printer/

This stl is designed to be printed in NYLON and therefore incorporates the cooling model for NYLON.
This part is for discussion purposes as the end use is a non-commercial electrical power generation windmill.
The user required a single unit to replace multi-part flanges on 29 existing installations located over a 2200 acre hillside farm and residence. Each unit connects to a self regulating alternator/inverter/battery system. All units are controlled and monitored via WiFi. Usage includes spot irrigation, animal surveillance, pump and other reservoir levels.
Due to the type of crops, there has been a larger than normal mortality of birds in the last few years. There was a request to modify all of the blade flanges in such a way as to provide a considerable â€œgiveâ€ or â€œdeflectionâ€ of the blades, yet keep generation efficiency at its current level. The â€œshoreâ€ value was provided by a local university.
Previous designs used spring-loaded hinges. After a short time, these would break and the mill would become unbalanced, and therefore unusable.
It was pointed out that while NYLON would provide the needed â€œshoreâ€, it was susceptible to water absorption from the elements. This would mean that the flanges would probably need to be replaced every 20-24 months depending on usage. The end user believes itâ€™s less costly to simply print out flanges and change them out when the mills are brought out from winter storage as opposed to a more expensive alternative.
This part is the REV â€œAâ€ design, but the fill has been changed to decrease the â€œshoreâ€ value after initial testing.
Each blade is aligned via two alignment pins, and held in place by an oval clamp.
As crop rotation takes place next year, effectively of the flange could take 4-5 years.
The only surprise in actual usage came from the fact that the NYLON replacement flange was so light, the millâ€™s alignment vane required some minor re-balancing.
A 12 unit field test will take place in late June.
The part is low res and designed to be printed with a .56 - .62 mm nozzle.
Even as the part is large, there is no corner lifting at 80% fill.
A heated table is not used. As in the photo, the part is printed on plain masking tape.
Material color on-hand is a reddish orange â€“ Field test parts will be printed in a dark tan.
The part was designed in Rhino, skinned in Slic3r v6 with no retraction and printed on a 2BEIGH3.
Retail material cost = $0.26

description.text:
This is the case for the Measure the Future sensor, based on a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B and a Logitech HD Webcam C525. There are two different setups for the sensor, one designed to sit on a shelf or ledge, and another designed to hang from a drop ceiling grid with a ball-joint for positioning.

You can mix and match the ceiling mounts as well. There's a Flat ceiling mount that can be screwed into a ceiling or mounted with double-sided mounting squares, or the drop ceiling mount that can be clipped over a ceiling grid.

If you need a different mounting type, please leave a comment and I'll see about adding it, or model it and let me know and I'll add it to the collection.

description.text:
The WoW miniature game is played with what is called uBases. They are underneath each miniature and they track ticks and health points. However, most of the time the bases do not work very well, plus it gets really, really annoying to lift up characters, twist the bases and then put the characters back on the board.

description.text:
I wanted a lightweight hook I could take along kayaking that could easily snag a drifting boat. I also wanted something that could use to lift outdoor furniture from ground level to a second-floor deck without carrying it through the house. There are probably many other uses.

UPDATE Version 2 (19 Jul. 2017):

In the original version the tines on hook are brittle when printed in PLA. Version 2 replaces those tines with #6 screws.

The hook attachment is sized for a 1/4-20 eye bolt. One nut is counter sunk in the bottom and the other nut and a toothed washer are tightened from the top to make it solid. Printed in PLA with 25% infill is sufficiently strong for my needs, but I'm not planning on tossing it on concrete.

Disclaimer: No testing has been done to establish a load limit. Do your own testing before relying on a print of this hook. Using this to climb buildings like in the original Batman TV series is particularly discouraged, but if you try it and live, please let me know.

author: jager_eenzaam

description.text:
This is based this on a few screenshots from the movie, which means it's correct for one scene, but may not be correct for all scenes, since animators sometimes take creative liberties when sizing items.

Parts are broken out so you can print everything in their actual color. You'll need supports on the center section where the gauge goes. Exploded view photo shows where all of the parts go.

Text on side and top of canister are embossed on canister, so you can just use a black paint pen for those instead of making decals or rub down type. You'll need to find your own caution stickers for the canister.

I have included several versions of the red gauge.
Version 1 is just a large red cylinder for those of you who can't print clear parts.

Version 2 is a red cylinder with a solid clear cover (for those of you who have a SLA/DLP to print clear).

Version 3 is the clear cover broken into sections with grey progress bars (again the clear is for SLA/DLP printers). You'll have to print 6 of the grey bars to insert between the clear sections.

There are several heights of the red progress cylinder for version 2 and version 3 gauges.

You should be able to drill holes in the back of the gauge back panel to add LEDs if you want.

UPDATE: I had several people ask me to bevel the back of the black gauge border to make it easier to fit into the yellow body. blackplatSC-Guage-Border-Black-thin.stl is the part you need if you want this option.
You can nail this dart holder to the wall. It has holes on the side for small nails. It should fit most darts.

remixed_from.author: ppet36
remixed_from.title: Yet another pen holder for Prusa i3

description.text:
Thanks go to ppet36 for his original design.

Rather than change the placement of my motor cabling, I changed the model to suit my printer. These are the files, separated and changed slightly. The rod bushing now has a tighter hole to accommodate my 3mm rod. Your mind now needs a change of drawers, go see mama. Printer is soon to also be a cnc pcb negative etcher, or a "see-peenee" for short... Yeah, okay I'm done.

The parts were haphazardly glued together with CA and water activator, the rod shoved into place and a rubber band to hold it under tension. Check out the lamja.com post http://www.lamja.com/?p=635 by Arvid for more details on etching pcbs using isolation routing via flatcam.

If you're following along with Arvids' tutorial don't forget to combine geometry. Otherwise you'll get a single pass only.

Known good settings for 3mm rod sharped to a point.

Tool Diam: 0.016 mm
Passes: >=5 but 5 seems perfect
Pass Overlap: 0.1 mm
Cut Depth -0.2 mm
Travel Z (zhop): 0.5 mm
Feed Rate: 15 (mm/s??) 25 still seems too fast and imprecise so 15 would be better.

Sample gcode and gerber bottom layer files included for ease of testing.
Thanks to freeduino.org for the board files I used
link: http://www.freeduino.org/freeduino_open_designs.html
Board size required is 80 mm x 60mm minimum for testing purposes.
Gcode sliced at 25, might be too fast for actual board, but good for quick testing.

G92 x0 y0 z0 is the gcode to set all points to zero, NOT M92!!!

Don't make that mistake and take an hour to figure out why the printer isn't moving. :/

G92 NOT M92

A test of fusion 360's new mesh lab

I used meshmixer to seperate and save as stl's. Then used fusion 360's new mesh lab preview to make a brep and then the changes needed from there. Pretty laggy new feature, but it worked well enough. Crashed once during the process.

title: DSLR 35mm Film Scanner Back Plate and Arca Mounting Plate

description.text:
MOVED TO: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2422903
Since I was working on all these bits and pieces, I decided to just put everything until one project so I'll be moving these over there along with my 6x4.5 and 6x6 designs. Also trying to figure out a good way to do spools on either side to better project uncut film.

I really liked emilhallengren's rig design (see remixed from) but ran into two minor issues: I couldn't find a plate that would fit the camera mount and I had some issues getting the film to run through the holder easily. I fixed the former by simply making a 3D printed plate that seems to fit, and added film guides and a bezel to the rear film holder. It's a bit annoying to get the film started but it seems to stay very well aligned once going. I might add a taper to one end of the holder to make insertion easier perhaps. That would help when scanning already cut strips, although if scanning an un-cut roll, once loaded it should go pretty quick.

Note that you will need to print most of emilhallengren's original design except for the back plate and, optionally, need to print the mount plate for the camera if yours does not fit.

print_settings.Notes:: I suggest you set the print so that this has no interior and use concentric patterns for the top and bottom.  This is as thick as the coin it is to replace, so make the number of top and bottom layers high enough so that the pattern goes all the way through the device.  Use a strong filament, and make sure it is well bonded.

title: openSCAD Parametric cart release tool - change size of disk - or anything else -  as needed, with text

description.text:
This device is designed to replace a coin that you might use to release a shoppng cart or trolley. The size of the "coin" piece can be changed easily, as can the other dimensions. The openSCAD source is included so that you can change the size as you need to and create a new STL. openSCAD is free, you can download it in a few minutes, edit the file with your favorite editor, then preview the device until you are happy with how the handle fits to the disk - and then you can finalize it and create a new STL.

See the openSCAD source for more information.

Sample stl files have been included for several common coins and to demonstrate some of the capabilities. The sort of thing that can be adjusted include:

  • Coin Size
  • Coin Thickness
  • Handle Width at base and tip
  • Whether a handle is generated or not
  • If a coin is not round, how many facets does it have
  • Whether text is to be inset on the handle.
  • Size and font of text
  • Depth of text
  • Whether the coin is hollow or filled,
  • Whether or not the handle has a rounded tip with a hole in it (for attaching to your keyring).
  • How large that hole should be.
  • Whether there are cutouts in your coin outline.
  • Where the cutouts are positioned, including positioning them far away from your main coin so that they do not affect the output at all.|
  • How much the handle should be rounded.

Defaults are included for many of these things. But using a different coin should be as simple as setting the thickness and diameter, and either changing or suppressing the text, and then generating an STL.

Edit: I looked at some of the other shopping cart token generators to see the sort of things that they were including. I have added (1) the ability to skip the handle, and to just print a plain disk, and (2) to print a disk that just has a border. I also allow for the printing of faceted disks in case the coin we are replacing is not round.

There are some example stls, but you should plan on installing openSCAD and creating your own stls. You can print a solid disk of the size you need, or a empty disk. You can print the handle with or without the keyring connector disk.

Other than a carabiner, if there is anything you want me to add to this, post. Bot. I thought I would never use that trig stuff, but I am using it to position the handle - I probably calculated the length of the distance from the center to the face in the most complex way.

6/23/2017: Modifications have been made so that the "bites" are always round even out of a faceted coin. Before, the same shape was used to make the bites as the shape of the disk, that only sort of worked for coins with even numbers of facets so I was pushing the bites out of the way - and sometimes things still didn't work. Disks with 12 or fewer facets are rotated so that a flat is perpendicular to the handle so that the handle and the disk can properly match - for 13 or more facets the presumption is that the coin is "round enough" so that the handle can mate anywhere. If you don't want bites out of your faceted coin, just set the biteSideOff factor to 2, just like you would do when generating a round coin with bites out of it.

The calculation of the handle attachment depth for faceted coins was simplified. I was using a correct but much overly complicated method for determining the minimum distance to a chord. Now I just use cosine.

6/23/2017 Edit 2: I added the ability to add one line of text to the handle. A sample stl file has been included to show how the text might work.

Unless there is a bug or I decide to rework the headers to allow for a coin to be specified, (and I can't decide how I would do that) I am unsure about what else I can do in terms of changing this. I have what I think is a good object with almost all the features one could want - well, no bottle opener or caribiner, but if you come from someplace where no one has created a shopping cart tool for your currency, you can do so by measuring your needed coin and just plugging in values, and so forth.

I probably spent more time getting faceted coins to work than any other single thing in the openSCAD code that describes the object, (since I just mostly copied the text code from another object I did) and I suspect that no one will ever use it. But if you have a square coin, I can generate a shopping cart tool for your coin, with or without bites out of it.

If you do make a tool for which I have not included the measurements, please let me know the name and nationality of the coin, and the measurements, and whether it has facets or is round, and whether or not you used the cutout tool, and in what proportions.

I will change the openSCAD and include a sample STL, and credit you in the object's comments.

The scad preview is failing, for whatever reason, the disk is not being shown. I suspect a difference in scad versions.

Notes:

I suggest you set the print so that this has no interior and use concentric patterns for the top and bottom. This is as thick as the coin it is to replace, so make the number of top and bottom layers high enough so that the pattern goes all the way through the device. Use a strong filament, and make sure it is well bonded.

openSCAD is a great tool. You can do amazing things with it. Think of how to mash basic shapes together. Works great, and you can allow the person who needs something like what you published but a variation with a different size or even relationship between parts of the object to change. In this case, just by changing some sizes, the printed object can he changed,`

title: Marble head of an athlete
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Marble head of an athlete
Period: Mid-Imperial, Antonine
Date: ca. A.D. 138 - 192
Culture: Roman
Medium: Marble Dimensions: H. 13 1/2 in. (34.3 cm)
Classification: Stone Sculpture
Credit Line: Rogers Fund, 1911
Accession Number: 11.210.2
This artwork is currently on display in Gallery 153
The Metropolitan Museum of Art
Scanned with 123DCatch on iPhone 5S on 26 Jan. 2014
http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections/248579?img=0 Copy of a Greek bronze statue of ca. 450 - 425 B.C. This head of a youth wearing a fillet (band) must have belonged to a statue of a victorious athlete. He probably rested one arm lightly on his head; the remains of a rectangular support can still be seen among his curls. Roman copies often conformed to contemporary taste, and the contrast between polished flesh and deeply drilled hair on this head would have held special appeal for clients in the second century A.D.

title: Component Lead Bender Caliper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is modeled after a tool that I saw in an old 1960's electronic hobbyist magazine the other day, with a few slight improvements. Component lead bending tools are nothing new on here, but this adds a level of precision to your bends. Simply place the points of the caliper in the two holes in to which you are going to install your component, place the part in the middle of the gap on top and bend the leads around the edges. For extra precision you can install a screw in the hole on top of the slide. Then, you can tighten down the slide so it can't move while you bend your leads. No more guessing how far apart you need to bend the legs of your resistors or any other axial leaded discreet component.

title: Mine Trolley for Stop Motion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Think Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, Hoodwinked, and maybe some spy vs spy and you have an idea of what I have in mind for this model. When I look at some of the pictures of mine trolleys on the web, this looks nothing like them, but that's OK.

The overall dimensions are 65mm wide x 70mm tall x 140mm long. The track gauge is about 38mm. The wheels have reasonably wide flanges and so can ride on rails up to about 40mm between rail centrelines.

The box on top was made from iceblock sticks stuck together with PVA glue. There is nothing special about this. The iceblock sticks were painted with a sepia coloured brown acrylic house paint without undercoat. This allowed the paint to penetrate the wood nicely and give an aged stained look. I have not included an STL for this part seeing as it is so simple to construct anyway.

Things you will need in addition to the printed bits;

  • 3 x 4mm rods of some sort for the axles. These are cut to 55mm long. I used dowel.
  • Popsicle sticks. The dimensions for the “planks” are provided here as a suggestion and are based on the standard popsicle stick size available here which are 10mm wide x 2mm thick x 113mm long.
    • 13 x 100mm long planks
    • 10 x 40mm planks
    • 8 x 50mm planks
    • 2 x 58mm planks
    • 4 x 15mm planks
  • Small screw to hold on the control lever if you are using it.
  • 1.5mm rod for the control lever
  • Some electrical tape or duct tape to made the handle on the control lever.
  • Glue. I use an epoxy glue, buy anything without too much flexibility will work.

In the model shown above, the channel sections used in the buffers were cardboard. This meant that I ended up with a slightly dinged up look to it, which suited the look I was after. The original digital model and all STLs include these channel sections.

When you print this you will end up with a handful of small components. Some assembly is required!

Included here is a pdf with this information together with assembly guide. I have also included an obj of the assembled model, and a .blend file.

I am putting my new models on Youmagine now as a preference, so head over there for a flying saucer.

Also the models are available on my website - Techmonkeybusiness.

title: 5.8mm holes for the large gear idler and gear pawl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
at the request of one of the users of my remix of the rolling chassis, it seems some people are having problems with some of the model tolerances. the original hole diameter for those items is 6.8mm and i've reduced it to 5.8mm using fusion 360. this should give anyone enough to play with so they can then shape the hole to their specific needs.

i have not printed this (as i do not need it personally), but i have been told by a user who did that 5.8mm did the trick for him.

1. create a new component in a fusion360 project.
  2. create a base feature (so you have some sort of editing and history ability).
  3. import mesh, and load the stl file - center it.
  4. right click on the mesh body and select mesh to brep. if it has too many triangles, perform a mesh reduce.
  5. merge faces as needed and clean things up, and click the "finish base feature".
  6. create a sketch on the top face of the hole, and create a sketch circle with the same diameter as the original using the 3-point-circumference circle tool.
  7. use that circle to create an offset of whatever you need, and then make the original circle a construction line.
  8. extrude - done...

A test pattern for debugging printrbot problems. May be useful to others.
The green example is PLA sliced to 0.1mm.
The red is ABS sliced to 0.2mm.

There are several .stl files. The testtextonly.stl just has text on a 1mm base. The test.stl is much larger and has extra shapes. In particular people are having trouble with Y axis motion and the zigzags test this.
Slic3r often screws up the zigzags - you can see this if you preview the g-code. Don't panic if they don't print. For people having trouble getting the first layer to stick - round shapes are easier. So I've added X.stl - a circular base with an X as another simple pattern. 100and50sqr-b.stl is what I use to calibrate X and Y steps. holetest.stl is just some differents sized holes. Rodtest is a test shape for checking printrbot rods are perpendicular. In particular people using their printers to print new printer parts should check everything is squared up. This is true for making other parts as well. The part has a 8mm tube to take a 8mm rod as used in the small PB.
The idea is to measure the rod angle against the flat bottom.
The cross shape can also be used to check X and Y are at 90 deg. Test123456 is something I did to test my cooling fan. Each number is 1mm higher than the one before so there is less and less time for the layers to cool. If you can print this your cooling is pretty good - but maybe too good? Ribtest (aka z-wobble).
This might get its own page later because it is a big subject. My test shape is a cylinder/tube.
Ribbing due to variable Z lift shows up most on thick walls and solids.
It also shows up more when using solid fill.
It typically shows up on .2mm or less slices but can show up on .4 if it is bad enough.
But there is more.
It is worse if you are over-extruding.
For plastic bots the ambient and motor temperature also matter because the motor mounts are softer when hot. This pattern also makes a good test for over-extrusion. The pattern is solid at the bottom - this shows up over extrusion and ribbing. Ribbing caused by Z lift will extend in all directions. Ribbing due to actual XY wobble won't do that. There is then a section with a hole in the centre. Z lift ribbing will also show up in the hole and the ribs will be the same "phase" as the ribs on the outside. IE it will bulge inwards at the same time as they bulge outwards. The top section is a 1mm walled tube.
I would expect ribbing to be much less in this section but I can't test it because my printer doesn't make ribs any more. Print this pattern solid at not more than .2mm slices. I also mention the ribbing issue here - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fu6An4-wFZQ The test prints in the image are .2mm for the bottom two and .1mm for the top one.
For the bottom right one I tried to make it wobble by loosening my mounting screws but it refused to do it.
All my other mods may have somethng to do with that.

title: Bracket for mounting RichRap's Greg's geared Bowden-extruder to 0.75" square-tube (like on a RigidBot)

description.text:
Bracket for mounting RichRap's Greg's geared Bowden-extruder to RigidBot (or any 0.75 inch square-tube frame)
RichRap's thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60531
I used #8-32 screws, but you can use an M4 also (they're essentially the same diameter). The part is about 28.6mm, or 1.125 (1 and 1/8th) in width, so your screws must be longer than that, plus the thickness of the extruder plate (3/16th inch or 5mm).
I recommend a high wall-thickness and a high density, for strength. Print however you'd like aside from that.

author: nabzim

title: GeeTech i3 pro C y belt holder

description.text:
A trussed y axis belt holder to fix the print bed to the belt on GeeTech i3 pro C and similar printers.
This replaces the odd aluminium block where you had to punch holes into your belt, that then start to tear the belt apart.
With the gap between the belt ends this works with the original belt that was used with the old block.

You need two M3 screws, 16 mm, 14 when you can get them, optionally two washers, and two M3 nuts. There are two nut holders, for square and hex nuts.

I fixed the nut holder to the large print bed with airplane glue. Like that you can replace the holder with a newer version, but just screwing it in place should work, too.

You can – and should, from time to time – easily tighten the screws with the print bed in place. (I ended up with many bad prints because the first version had shaken itself lose, and the only way to the screws was to unscrew the whole print bed.)

This should be easy to adapt for other printers where the belt holder is attached with two screws. Just put your printer’s measure into the scad file and render it.

This is the second version. You need two parts, the holder and a part to fix the nuts above the large bed holder plate. I glued the nut holder in place with airplane glue.

As usual, you can find design history at my github repo.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2613389

A GoPro Session mount for the R5X(LX). This is primarily designed for top mounting a battery but can just as well be used for bottom mounted batteries.

Included is 25 degree, 35 degree and 45 degree versions.

I have honed this design quite a lot to ensure the props are out of frame and that it withstands a beating.

I love the R5LX frame but have always preferred a top mounted battery, and running the frame bottom mounted confirmed this for me. The problem is that the frame is not designed for it, with slight modifications to the top plate and this mount you can get back to flying those top mounted batteries.

Doesn't Matter

20-40

Notes:

Strongly recommend using TPU or a similar flexible filament.

The marked areas need cut or widened for battery top mounting.

The top small circles need cut or the gap a little wider to fit screws through. The large circle needs cut to run a battery strap through.

Once the modifications have been made simply run screws through the mount and attach with bolts on the underside.

A fast linear actuator for servo : servo 180° rotation on XY plane -> 58mm on Z plane
2 versions of the rings are available

A: linear_ring_1.stl has wide tolerance, about 0.8mm away the inside worm screw
B: linear_ring_T.stl has a small tolerance, about 0.25mm

"A" version needs rough sanding only, but has more axial parasitic move tolerance

both pieces needs sanding
use grease for smooth working of the thing

A tool for safely removing 608 standard bearings from spinners, without damaging either. This is my take on a bearing remover, I recommend using a vice along with this for optimal results, rubber/plastic hammer should work also. There is a tool similar to this in thingiverse, but I was missing a middle pole to easily "aim" the bearing to the middle, I made this from scratch so don't even start blaming me of copying it, apart from the basic idea. If there is a problem I've missed with the mechanics of the design, please inform me and I'll fix it, this is an early version that I will modify if needed.
I recommed using 0.1mm layers with 100% infill if you are looking for a sturdy print, also the plunger diameter is exactly 22mm so let me know if you need a version with some tolerances. 50%-75% -ish fill should suffice for light use.
Enjoy and please don't copy or sell without consulting me first!

comments.text: It would be helpful if you could make it be a bit less exact, the first time I used it the bearing got stuck and i had to cut it out, this was after i got the top stuck on without a bearing in it. otherwise it was great and I like the design better than any of the others ive seen.
comments.author: millemnm

comments.text: I'll take that into consideration, currently on vacation so don't have access to SolidWorks. Referring to my last comment, an easy fix is to sand the "plunger" part just a bit so it slides out easier. You can also sand the inside diameter a bit. The reason for the exact measurements is that putting pressure on anything but the outside ring of a bearing can damage it. Thanks for the comment and I'll modify it a bit after the holidays.
comments.author: millemnm

comments.text: After using this for a while, I recommend sanding down the outside diameter, of the plunger. Don't get carried away, just take away enough so it slips off the slot(of your spinner) easier. :)
comments.author: humppanukke

OpenScad

title: Push Block Light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-- IMPORTANT -- Il s'agit là d'un outil de sécurité. Je ne suis pas ingénieur, mais un simple utilisateur d'imprimante 3D et à ce titre, si vous deviez vous blesser à cause du Push Block Light, ni moi ni Thingiverse ne pourrions être responsable. Si vous décidez d'imprimer le Push Block,Light vous prenez seul la responsabilité de l'utiliser à vos risques et périls.

Lorsque l'on souhaite juste pousser un bout de bois pour faire une découpe rapide, ma version réglable du Push Block (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2056511) n'est pas l'outil le plus rapide à utiliser.

Avec cette version light, aucun réglage n'est possible, mais elle suffit à faire le travail.

Il y a deux poignées de disponible : une en 20mm de large et la deuxième en 25mm de large. Vous pouvez choisir celle qui vous convient le mieux.

Les vis qui retiennent les crochets à l'arrière afin qu'ils puissent rester en place lorsque l'on manipule le Push Block Light, sont en Ø4 mm pour 30 mm de long. Le trou fait Ø3.5 mm et de cette façon, vous pouvez soit utiliser un taraud de Ø4 mm pour créer un pas de vis comme je l'ai fais, soit utiliser une vis de Ø3 mm avec un écrou. Dans tous les cas, ne visser pas trop fort, la pièce doit pouvoir coulisser, cette vis ne suffit aucun effort.

Pour la poignée vous devez utiliser un écrou M5 et un boulon M5 de 30mm.La poignée peut être tournée suivant un angle de 15°

Comme avec la version réglable, pour le revêtement anti-adhérant j'ai utilisé la même plaque de caoutchouc : http://www.leroymerlin.fr/v3/p/produits/plaque-en-caoutchouc-290-x-210-mm-e1400037406?queryredirect=a_fp_plaque_en_caoutchouc__290_x_210_mm&numpage=1

J'espère que vous aimerez cette version light.

English version

(sorry for my poor English)

-- WARNING -- It is security tool. I am not an engineer, but a simple user of 3D printer and for this reason, if you injury you because of Push Block Light, neither me nor Thingiverse let us can be responsible. If you decide to print the Push Block Light, you take the responsibility to use it at your risks.

When you just want to push a piece of wood to make a quick cut, my adjustable version of the Push Block (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2056511) is not the fastest tool to use .

With this light version, no adjustment is possible, but it is enough to do the work.

There are two handles available: one in 20 mm wide and the second in 25 mm wide. You can choose the one that suits you best.

The screws that hold the hooks at the back so they can stay in place when handling the Push Block Light, are Ø4 mm for 30 mm long. The hole is Ø3.5 mm and this way you can either use a tap of Ø4 mm to create a screw thread as I did, or use a screw of Ø3 mm with a nut. In any case, do not screw too hard, the part must be able to slide, this screw is not enough effort.

For the handle you must use an M5 nut and an M5 bolt of 30 mm. The handle can be rotated at an angle of 15 °

Like with the adjustable version, for the non-skid coating I used the same rubber plate: http://www.leroymerlin.fr/v3/p/produits/plaque-en-caoutchouc-290-x-210-mm-e1400037406?queryredirect=a_fp_plaque_en_caoutchouc__290_x_210_mm&numpage=1

I hope you enjoy this light version.

title: 'Bobblerz'
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Bobblerz... just 'Bobble'. Very likeable little things (that are quick and easy to print) and bring a smile to your face every time you tap them down onto a sold surface (keep holding the body) and watch them... bobble.

They're a fun little head that bobbles up / down / sideways on an internally printed spring. Just give your Bobbler a shake and watch it 'bobble'...just like watching a fidget spinner spin!

Everyone that sees them likes them and most want one... so they make great little gifts... and as they require just 16 - 18gm filament at standard scale (....and yes they can be uniformly scaled up okay to a certain extent) they aren't expensive to print.

A range of Bobblerz .stl's is provided... choose your favourite (refer to images to see the selection) or print them all and create a family of 'Bobblerz'. You can even get creative with them by painting the eyes and mouth or pausing your machine mid-print and swapping the filament so you have your own unique Bobbler/z.

Bobblerz are easy to use / have fun with. Just hold the body part then tap them down onto a solid surface, hold them down and don't let go. This makes them 'bobble' best... if you let go much of the energy is lost into the body through vibration so they don't 'bobble as well or for as long. The body part is important as it provides a holding mechanism independent of the internal spring but also limits the sideways spring movement minimizing the chance of breaking them (...because PLA is very brittle).

Competed prints will have four fine bridges which have been designed in to stop the Bobblerz from bobbling during printing... as that would cause all sorts of print issues. These bridges run from the top of the body inwards to the neck section. They should be quick and easy to snap away to leave your 'Bobblerz' free to bobble... have fun with them!

You can also add colour the facial features to make them stand out more. If you decide to do this using an enamel paint and very fine brush is recommended. Felt tip pens and acrylic paints are more prone to running / smearing.

These are all easy prints on accurate / precise well set up machines. However, do not use any automated support or you are likely to end up with a spring that isn't springy so a Bobbler that doesn't bobble.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information... and post images of all your 'Bobblerz' for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Standard / 0.20mm

PLA / 2 Shells / 20% recommended

Notes:

Easy print on an accurate / precise / well set up PLA machine with a filament cooling fan... do NOT use any support.

Recommend printing in the centre of your build plate as this will help minimize movement during printing (Printing off centre can result in build plate sway/tilt movement)

Just one quick and easy task to start bobbling...

Competed prints will have four fine bridges which have been designed in to stop the Bobblerz from bobbling during printing... as that would cause all sorts of print issues. These bridges run from the top of the body inwards to the neck section. They should be quick and easy to snap away... leaving you with bobbling 'Bobblerz'... have fun with them!

Note: If you want to add colour the facial features using an enamel paint and very fine brush is recommended. Felt tip pen and acrylic paints are more prone to running / smearing.

comments.author: bigibomb

comments.text: Hi... I can make the supports thicker but as long as your machine is well set up, has a nice level build plate and you are printing dead centre, plus your filament fan is cooling effectively it should be okay. The issue you've described suggests too much machine vibration, build plate movement (rocking), or insufficient cooling. Scaling it up a fraction may help as it will thicken up the spring. You could also increase the fill % and slow the outline speed down. These could all help... hopefully you can get it working well for you. As the images show I've printed lots and on several machines with no issues...

comments.text: As always, love the design. Downloaded right away as I had an immediate idea for use for them. I do think the neck could use a little more support. So far each print the neck supports have broken during printing and the head started to move. Some worse than others. Maybe fatten the existing supports or add a few more?
comments.author: tinkerz

comments.text: Thanks for your feedback.  I minimized the supports as much as possible but they are thicker than I used on prototypes. I can add more easily if I receive more reports of the same issue. However for them to break it suggests excessive vibration or insufficient filament cooling.  It's worth adding that printing in the dead centre of your build plate usually ensures the least potential for build plate movement. ... I hope this helps. If not let me know and extra support can be added... but they should print fine on a well set up machine. Check your levelling as well.
comments.author: tinkerz

comments.text: I agree, it's very likely a machine induced issue. The Trinus is a Y-axis bed moment printer so yes there is a great deal of vibration on the part. It's the nature of the mechanics on this type. And I don't expect you to change the model on one report. ;-) Just wanted to make sure you had the feedback. ;-) As always, love your work. Keep it up!
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: You may find scaling it up a fraction makes all the difference. If that forces the machine to add an extra layer to those small supports it could make them hold adequately. there's a fine line where different slicing apps change layers so enlarging it by a very small amount could potentially increase the height of that support by another layer, although the change in scale would be far less... if you understand my explanation. 5% would probably be enough. I hope this helps!
comments.author: tinkerz

comments.text: Why the no derivative licence? I understand the no commercial, but not allowing remixes stops a very imaginative community from adding characters to the family.
comments.author: Lee-R

comments.text: Pleased you like them... obviously you can do your own thing for your own use. However, although it may sound strange but my decision to specify 'no derivatives' is for self preservation. From (lots of) past experience I learned that allowing derivatives usually results in lots of people having issues with some of the derivatives and they come back to me (as the design originator) asking for support or hurling abuse.... yes it happens!

title: Christmas Tree Isosurface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A slight tweak to my code for the Twisted Drop, with a stretch and a Boolean merge with a cone to give a trunk and remove some of the weirdness inside the tree.

Printer:

Eaglemoss Vector3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

I started with some code I give my students to help them start 3D graphics projects. This helps them create models in Vertex and Index Buffers programmatically. I then grabbed the Marching Cubes function from here, and used it so that I could feed in an equation and get out a Vertex Buffer containing a given isosurface of that equation, display it and then spits out a basic obj file.

My wife commented that the twisted drop looked a bit like a Christmas tree, so I slightly tweaked the code for it to produce this.

The model is in a cubic region 2 Pi to a side and centred at the origin, with a grid of values 100 x 100 x 100 and the isosurface value is zero.

This left a few odd bits of other geometry junk in that region, so when I pulled it in to Netfabb to stitch it all together I also removed all of them apart from this piece which I also slightly stretched.

The geometry got a bit strung out and tortured on the inside of the "tree", so I Boolean added a plain cone to cover it up and act as a trunk

This is the code which calculates the function / equation value for a given point in space

float VBMarchCubes::function(Vector3 _pos)
{
_pos *= 2.0;
float w = _pos.z *1.2f;
float x = (_pos.x *cos(w) - _pos.y * sin(w))/(0.25*(_pos.z+XM_PI)), y = (_pos.x*sin(w)+_pos.y*cos(w)) /(0.25* (_pos.z + XM_PI)), z = _pos.z*cos(w)*cos(w);
float x1 = _pos.x, y1 = _pos.y, z1 = _pos.z;
return ((x + 1)*(x + 1) + (y + 1)*(y + 1) + (z - 2)*(z - 2) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)*((x - 1)*(x - 1) + (y - 1)*(y - 1) + (z - 2)*(z - 2) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)
*((x - 1)*(x - 1) + (y + 1)*(y + 1) + (z - 1)*(z - 1) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)*((x + 1)*(x + 1) + (y - 1)*(y - 1) + (z - 1)*(z - 1) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)
*((x + 1)*(x + 1) + (y + 1)*(y + 1) + (z + 1)*(z + 1) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)*((x - 1)*(x - 1) + (y - 1)*(y - 1) + (z + 1)*(z + 1) - XM_PIDIV2*XM_PIDIV2)
*((x1*x1 / (XM_PI*XM_PI) + y1*y1 / (XM_PI*XM_PI) + (z1 - 4)*(z1 - 4) / (XM_PIDIV4*XM_PIDIV4)) - 1);
}

description.text:
The FA-200 is a light 4 seater aeroplane that was produced from 1968 to 1986 by Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan. It's pretty similar in performance to a Piper PA-28 Cherokee, but, unlike most planes, it's also rated for aerobatics.

This model has an option for a weight in the nose to keep the tail off the ground. It's designed for a 5/16" (8mm) diameter, 1" (25mm) long metal shaft. I used a spare bolt, but a solid shaft would be better. If you want the weighted version, use the file "Fuji_FA-200_Weighted". Otherwise, just use "Fuji_FA-200".

Printer:

MeCreator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

No less that 15%, no more than 25%

Notes:

Don't worry about the hole for the weight having a support in it, I found if you put a knife around the side of the support and twist it, the support just pops out (sometimes at great speed, don't put your face too close).

The weighted version is designed for a 5/16" (8mm) thick, 1" (25mm) long shaft. Before gluing the 2 halves together, I recommend
A) Checking that the halves line up with the weight inside (if they don't you may need to file down one side of the shaft),
B) Checking that the weight is heavy enough to hold the nose down (use blu-tac to temporarily hold the halves together), and
C) Gluing the weight into position, so that you don't get an annoying rattle coming from inside the plane.

Length of the weight Thickness of the weight
Built from a set of blueprints using SketchUp, minor modifications carried out after using Tinkercad.

I noticed the 1" extrusion for the door on the lathe enclosure was just slightly longer than the lower gutter they include with the enclosure so I whipped these little gutters up to help keep coolant in the lathe and off the floor. Install them in place of the standard end caps using the factory push fastener or you can tap the rail with a 1/4-20 tap and use short stainless bolts like i did.

The one with the larger 45º angle is labeled "RH" and goes on the right end of the rail as you're looking at the machine. The LH one has a smaller angle to clear the higher lower drip tray end.

author: WillLyon

title: Airbrush CNC Support and control with Marlin

description.text:
I know i'm not the first thinking about this, but i can tell you how i did it if you want.
This is a special support to be placed in a CNC/3DP wich uses the Extruder Motor connection and a 9g servo to control an airbrush.

You can join the group CNC Airbrushing if you want to go deeper with this.

So you will think your airbrush doesn't fit. I designed this for a double action side feed airbrush worth about 30€.

I also used 2 608 bearings, a M8 large bolt, 2 M8 nuts, a 5mm to 8mm coupling, 4 M3x20 for bearing top and airbrush jacket, another larger M3 to attach jacket to body, a TowerPro 9g servo and a Nema17 stepper.

Te stepper is used to control amount of paint, and the servo just control the air flow.

This is my V2 for this project. I previously used 2 servos but Mcode is not sync with the rest of the XYZE code, so i had some problems with definition in some points.

If you plan to experiment with this, you must know that is way more easy to make drawings lets say like a plotter. I mean making lines without changin amount of paint is easy compared with controlling amount of paint shot for each mm.

My bests trys of printing B/N photos by now are made using CNC sofware to make a 3D raster over a Z-height from grayscale model. I use top of "stock material" as origin, and then all "-ZXXX" text in the gcode is replaced by "EXXX".

At the beggining of the program, just after the airbrush is moved over the start point you must "open air" with a M280 Sxx command and close it in the last point of the raster.

Im working by now in 1/2 A4 or A4 but i think this would be better for bigger sizes. If i get complete control over this technique i will paint my bedroom curtains in 6 panels of 100x50 aprox.

The worse part of all this compared to 3dp is the 92db my air compressor makes :S.

If you want to see it in action airbrushing an image please take a look at this video:
video

Will you give it a try?¿?

Just another head? You can see this thing just as another posible head to mount onto a MPCNC. So as a base you will need the knowledge about building and controlling a CNC machine and a 3D printer. As there is no software exactly for this purpose, you will need to make your own software chain and a little of "magic" to get the features you want. As i quickly explained in the summary, this magic is using CNC cutting software to generate the XYZ gcode, then "text edit" this code to replace parts of the code and add some commands manually or with a macro.

Start gcode Here is an example of my start gcode and the start of a raster. The machine initializates, the stepper E coordinates are set to 0 and the servo is positioned in close position. If you send a "G1 E1 F1200" you would move the needle of the airbrush 1mm up at 1200mm/min and partially open paint flow but would be no air pressure so probably you would get a ink drop. After the initialization, the head moves over the initial raster position, the servo moves to press the air flow button of the airbrush and inmediately the head start to move over the raster in sync with the E stepper at the desired speed. ( Initialization Parameters )
G90 ; Absolute Coords
G21 ; units in mm
G28 ; XYZ Homing
G92 E0 ; 0 setting paint flow
( Initial Servo Position for CLOSED AIR flow )
G4 P2 ; 2 ms pause
M280 P0 S55 ; S0 and S127 would be extreme positions
G4 P2 ; 2 ms pause
( Initial XYZ position for my machine )
G1 X0.000 Y0.000 Z150.000 F1800.0 ( Raster Code Start )
( Initial XY positions of the example raster and desired Z )
G0 X316.954 Y131.449 Z5.000 F2100
( Open Air Flow )
G4 P1 ; 1ms pause for sync of mcode
M280 P0 S35 ; Servo 1 moves so the air flow button is pressed
G1 E0.632 F1200.0 ; The raster starts opening 0.6mm the paint flow
G1 Y131.951 E0.897
G1 Y132.955 E0.915
G1 Y133.958 E1.088
G1 Y135.213 E0.672
G1 Y135.966 E0.596
G1 Y136.468 E0.427
G1 Y137.221 E0.514 And the raster goes on... End gcode So here is the code i use when the raster ends. In the last point of the raster first the paint flow gets closed and then the air flow. After that the head lifts and goes to XY 0 and steppers are unelectrified. G1 Y142.741 E0.891
G1 Y141.236 E1.031
G1 Y140.483 E1.292
G1 Y131.449 E1.300 ; this is the last point of the raster ( Raster final code )
G1 E0 ; close paint flow
( Close air flow )
G4 P2 ; 2ms pause
M280 P0 S55 ; servo moves to non-pressing position
G4 P10 ; 10ms pause ( Machine final code )
G1 F1800 Z180 ; lift the head up a lot
G1 F3600 X0 Y0 ; move head to XY origin
M18 ; disable stepper motors

Shake your pocket baby!
  • A CNC or 3D Printer machine controled by Arduino + RAMPS + Marlin Firmware
  • Side feed airbrush like mine
  • Air compressor with manometer and able to sustain 0.5-1,5 bar pressure during print time
  • Adaptors and hoses to connect them and extra manometer near the airbrush if possible
  • Some quality paint for airbrusing and the appropriate solvent
  • Lots of second hand papers or fabrics to try over

• airbrushing concepts
  • gcode language
  • firmware edition
  • CNC configuration
  • tool limits
  • CAD
  • CAM
  • openware thinking

comments.text: Hi Joao! I use a photo to generate a 3d model in wich the Z (height) of each point corresponds to the darkness of the associated pixel. Then i use CNC software to generate the gcode doing a 3d Raster over the generated model. Then i replace the Z axis coordinates with E coordinates. I also make some other adjustements and adds to the code so finally the head of the machine only moves in XY doing a raster but the E axis coordinates makes the airbrush shoot more or less paint. If you talk portuguese maybe we understand better each other in Portuñol :) Say me something by private if you want to know more.
comments.author: salema

comments.text: This is the solution I was looking for. Thanks for sharing! How do you "tune" the E axis so that the move to the next X,Y coordinate is timed appropriately?
comments.author: dlb5

comments.text: The smoothness of the movement is influenced from the feed rate and the max acc and speed of each of the axis motors. My extruder motor just moves the needle 1mm up and down. If this motos speed or acc is very low the airbrush xy speed will have speed reductions where there is a sudden change from black to withe or viceversa. If the feedrate XY is slow the extruder motor will have enough time to move over high contrast zones without making XY movement reduce its speed.
comments.author: leaptech

comments.text: I may have missed it.  What are you using for steps per unit on E0?
comments.author: dlb5

comments.text: The M8 screw normal pitch i think is 1.25mm. So 200steps (1 turn) with no microstepping should lift the airbrush needle 1.25mm. So it should be 200/1.25 = 160 steps with no microstepping to lift needle 1mm. And for example, for a 8 microsteps per step config, it should be 160x8 = 1280 steps. Double it for 16 microsteps per step. I think this is how it works :)

title: Coffee Stencil - Five-Petal Flower - New Style
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 7/5/2017: Stencil Update! I've uploaded the new version of the stencil, with a resized opening, sturdy handles, and an identification icon on the handle itself! I'm also keeping the original file just in case some people don't like handles that stay on, and icons for easy identification!

Old: Flower_Five_90mm_Starbucks_16oz_v3.stl
New: NEW_Flower_Five_90mm_Starbucks_16oz_v2.stl

Edit 6/30/2017: Something-something flower pun, download the stencil holder here!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2412238

Edit 6/29/2017: I've created a new stencil of a butterfly, with a new handle design! All new stencils going forward will have this improved design, and I will retrofit all previous stencils shortly....

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2410534

Edit 6/28/2017: Dial your friends from the 60s, Flower Child, with this phone stencil:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2409377

Edit 6/26/2017: A perfect pair with this flower stencil? A new leaf stencil!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2405021

Edit 6/24/2017: Another stencil? The Dude abides!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402130

Edit 6/23/2017: Caffeine and flowers go great together, and my new smiley face stencil is yet another way to put a smile on your face (and coffee in your belly!):

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2400553

Edit 6/21/2017: Lucy, my Shih Tzu (bless you!) wants me to remind you that she's pretty, and is the cute puppy modeling the stencil today. She's asked for future gigs - we'll see. I don't want it going to her head! Oh, and here's a picture of Lucy being extra cute and dolled-up:

https://www.flickr.com/photos/theamarand/4758120065

--End of Edits--

Oh, the humanity!

Wait, no, a flaming crashing German passenger airship has nothing whatsoever to do with this pretty Thing. Nothing at all! The Hindenburg may have been a disaster, but this five-petal flower coffee stencil is anything but.... If you are here for the Hindenburg, here's a link (please come back after you've read all about this historical event!):

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindenburg_disaster

So I started with a heart, because a lot of people like hearts. Then I realized people also enjoy five-pointed stars, because of patriotism and, well, stars are cool. Then, I had a whole bunch of ideas flood into my head, but my favorite was the flower. Finding a design that is simple enough was challenging, but a five-petal flower gives you just enough detail to know it's a flower, without being too detailed. It is, after all, for dusting powder onto the top surface of a beverage (or something else, if you're feeling creative). Too little detail, and people are going to say "what's that?!" and with too much detail, people are going to say "is it a...blob?" Why yes, yes it is.

As mentioned, there's a heart and a star. If you're all like "flowers suck!" then here are the other stencils for your flower-hating beverage enjoyment:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2393694
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2395326

It's interesting to see which of these stencils is becoming more popular. Obviously, people love hearts. They're curvy and pointy, just like love! Stars are cool too, but they're 100% pointy and stabby. Flowers, on the other hand, are extra curvy. So we'll see how this compares to other shapes.

This design works great with a lot of different travel cups and mugs. Ideally, your vessel is smaller than 90mm, but not too small. If you find that you need a larger or smaller opening, and/or a stencil opening to accommodate the different size, just let me know! I know that I give a decent margin around the outside of the stencil, so you could probably go almost down to the size of the stencil opening, just don't forget to leave a margin for white-space.

The quickest way to get an official, different sized, different shaped stencil is just to leave comments on this Thing. For a collaborative effort, go ahead and download the Thing that's closest to what you need, print it out (it shouldn't take too long), and then post an I Made One here on the site, associated with the correct Thing. Then we can share pictures and comments, figuring out the size of your cup opening, the depth needed (sometimes, if cups are more curvy, they need a taller stencil lip), and even maybe a sketch of a unique stencil you'd like me to create! If you want your username in the final version, I can do that, for sure, for a little bit of collaboration credit. I'll probably mention you right here in the Summary too, because why not?

Other than that, it's super easy to use. Just go to the Post-Printing section below, where you'll find a YouTube video that'll get you started!

If you think life is hard, think about a bird, building a nest, with no opposable thumbs - just it's beak and talons:

https://www.flickr.com/photos/theamarand/17937326245/

Yup, that's a much harder life!

Feel free to post comments, share your makes with the I Made One facility here, and maybe even a remix? I like remixes.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Easy printing, just make sure the bed is extra-level, and not shimmying around, because, as mentioned earlier, the "connector" lines are very thin (0.6mm) and fragile (by design). Once again, please take extra care in removing this part from the bed. I know it's not a real disaster like this:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindenburg_disaster#/media/File:Hindenburg_disaster.jpg

...but having your flower center mistakenly broken off can be sad:

How to Use

The art of coffee stenciling dates back to...wait, no, you don't care about that. What you do care about is how to actually do it. Here's a video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8ugnBwyCgk

This stencil requires very little clean-up if you're lucky and leveled.

Please be careful when removing this print from the bed. The 0.6mm "connectors" that hold the flower-center connected are very thin by design. Try to be careful to use your removal tool along these lines, and try to remove the flower-center along with the rest of the piece. I suspect, if you pull the outside too hard, with the center still attached, it'll probably break off. If you're going for a centerless-flower, congratulations, you now have a centerless flower! Otherwise, just reprint, and be more careful next time.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

It's great that I can just take my original stencil base, remove the stencil opening, and create a "CLEAN" version that I can then use to design new stencils. It's very easy to do, and even easier once I have the "clean" version ready to go.

If you have an SVG file, and want me to make and share a custom stencil, you can send me a URL to the SVG file, send me a private message, comment here...whatever works. I can also convert most images from a raster file into a vector file, but if it's not a simple, clean design, and it takes too much work, I'll probably say yes, but never get around to it. You've seen what works in the stencils I've designed so far. Don't send me this picture and think it's going to work out (protip: it won't):

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0852863/mediaviewer/rm3873103616

Keep it simple, and you'll have a custom stencil in no time!
